entity1.name: Bicycle
entity1.description: An early type of bicycle that featured pedals attached directly to the front wheel, also known as the 'boneshaker'.;;;A two-wheeled vehicle propelled by the rider, typically with pedals and a simple frame.;;;A vehicle with two wheels propelled by foot pedals, used for transportation or recreation.;;;An early form of bicycle invented by Baron Karl von Drais, which was improved upon by the boneshaker.;;;A two-wheeled vehicle propelled by pedals, used for transportation and recreation.;;;The structural framework of a bicycle that supports the rider and other components such as wheels, pedals, and seats.;;;A two-wheeled vehicle propelled by pedals and steered with handlebars attached to the front wheel.;;;A mode of transportation characterized by having two wheels, such as a bicycle or motorcycle.;;;The activity or sport of riding bicycles, which gained significant popularity with the introduction of the safety bicycle.;;;An early human-powered vehicle, often considered a precursor to the bicycle.;;;A type of bicycle equipped with an electric motor to assist the rider, allowing for easier and longer rides.;;;A human-powered vehicle with two wheels, typically propelled by pedals.;;;A type of bicycle popular in the 19th century, characterized by a large front wheel and a much smaller rear wheel.;;;Cycling that focuses on achieving high speeds and optimal performance, often associated with professional or elite cyclists.;;;A type of bicycle that was safer and easier to ride than its predecessors, leading to increased popularity in the late 19th century.;;;An early type of bicycle characterized by a large front wheel and a much smaller rear wheel, popular in the late 19th century.;;;High-performance bicycles designed for competitive cycling events.;;;A type of bicycle that was safer and more comfortable to ride, leading to increased popularity in the late 19th century.;;;A type of bicycle that features two wheels of equal size, a chain drive system, and pneumatic tires, designed to be more stable, comfortable, and efficient than earlier bicycles.;;;An early two-wheeled vehicle without pedals, invented by Baron Karl von Drais in the early 19th century. It was propelled by the rider pushing off the ground with their feet.;;;Another name for the high-wheel bicycle, named after British coins to describe its size difference between the two wheels.;;;A vehicle with two wheels, typically propelled by pedals and steered with handlebars.;;;Motor vehicles designed primarily for passenger transportation on roads.;;;A two-wheeled vehicle propelled by human power.;;;A human-powered vehicle with two wheels, typically used for transportation or recreation.;;;A type of bicycle designed for speed, typically with dropped handlebars and a more aerodynamic riding position.

entity3.name: 19th century
entity3.description: The period of time from 1801 to 1900, characterized by significant industrial and technological advancements.;;;The period from around 1870 to 1900, characterized by significant technological and social changes.
entity3.chunkid: The Evolution of the Bicycle2;;;The Evolution of the Bicycle10

entity4.name: carbon fiber
entity4.description: A type of frame material used in bicycles, known for being lightweight, strong, and aerodynamic.;;;A strong, lightweight material used in various applications including bicycle manufacturing.;;;A strong, lightweight material made from thin fibers of carbon, used in various applications requiring high strength-to-weight ratio.;;;A strong and lightweight material made from thin fibers of carbon, used in various applications including bicycle construction.
entity4.chunkid: The Evolution of the Bicycle2;;;The Evolution of the Bicycle17;;;The Evolution of the Bicycle18;;;The Evolution of the Bicycle16

entity5.name: Baron Karl von Drais
entity5.description: A German inventor who created an early version of the bicycle called the 'draisine' in the early 19th century.

entity8.name: mid-19th century
entity8.description: A period in history that spans from the 1850s to the 1860s.

entity11.name: boneshaker
entity11.description: An early type of bicycle that was a significant improvement over the draisine, offering a smoother ride and greater speed.

entity17.name: front wheel
entity17.description: The larger wheel located at the front of the bicycle, contributing to its distinctive appearance and high center of gravity.

entity18.name: rear wheel
entity18.description: The smaller wheel located at the back of the bicycle, providing support and balance in conjunction with the front wheel.

entity20.name: wealthy gentlemen
entity20.description: A class of affluent men who had the means to afford expensive hobbies or pastimes, such as riding a penny-farthing.

entity27.name: 20th century
entity27.description: A period of 100 years from the year 1901 to 2000.;;;The period from 1901 to 2000, characterized by significant technological and social changes.
entity27.chunkid: The Evolution of the Bicycle16;;;The Evolution of the Bicycle13

entity28.name: steel
entity28.description: A strong and durable metal alloy, primarily composed of iron with a small percentage of carbon.;;;A common alloy of iron and carbon, widely used for its strength and durability in construction and manufacturing.
entity28.chunkid: The Evolution of the Bicycle14;;;The Evolution of the Bicycle15

entity30.name: aluminum
entity30.description: A lightweight, durable metal used as an alternative to steel in various applications.

entity31.name: titanium
entity31.description: A strong, corrosion-resistant metal that is lighter than steel and often used in high-performance applications.

entity36.name: Competitive racing
entity36.description: A form of sport where participants compete against each other to determine the fastest rider or team.

entity39.name: bicycle manufacturing
entity39.description: The process of designing and producing bicycles for commercial sale.

entity43.name: cruisers
entity43.description: A type of bicycle designed for comfort, often featuring upright seating positions and wide tires suitable for casual riding.

entity48.name: public transportation
entity48.description: A shared transport service that is available for use by the general public, typically provided by government or private operators.

entity49.name: Tour de France
entity49.description: A famous multi-stage bicycle race primarily held in France, known for its challenging routes and prestigious status in the world of cycling.

entity51.name: human ingenuity
entity51.description: The ability to think outside the conventional patterns and come up with innovative ideas.;;;The capacity of humans to invent and solve problems using creative skills and intelligence.

entity53.name: perseverance
entity53.description: The steadfastness in doing something despite difficulty or delay in achieving success.

entity55.name: future
entity55.description: A period of time that is yet to come, often associated with predictions and expectations.
